title: 114_hr2017
content: The Act titled "Common Sense Nutrition Disclosure Act of 2015" amends disclosure requirements for restaurants and retail food establishments. The Act "Common Sense Nutrition Disclosure Act of 2015" amends Section 403(q)(5)(H) of the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act to specify calorie information for standard menu items in restaurants and retail food establishments. The Act "Common Sense Nutrition Disclosure Act of 2015" amends Section 403(q)(5)(H) of the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act to specify calorie information for standard menu items in restaurants and retail food establishments. The amendment includes changes to how calorie information is presented for standard menu items, allowing for more detailed breakdowns of calories per serving or per common unit division. The Act "Common Sense Nutrition Disclosure Act of 2015" modifies the disclosure requirements for calorie information in restaurants and retail food establishments. It allows for calorie information to be provided through remote-access menus and includes more detailed breakdowns of calories per serving or common unit division. The Act "Common Sense Nutrition Disclosure Act of 2015" amends disclosure requirements for calorie information in restaurants. It allows for nutrient content disclosures to vary from actual content due to factors like serving size variations or human error in preparation. The Secretary will establish standards for disclosing nutrient content for menu items with different flavors or combinations, allowing flexibility for restaurants to choose how to disclose the information. The Secretary will establish standards for disclosing nutrient content for menu items with different flavors or combinations, allowing flexibility for restaurants to choose how to disclose the information, including using ranges, averages, individual labeling, or a preset standard build. The Secretary may also allow other methods with a reasonable basis. The Common Sense Nutrition Disclosure Act of 2015 requires the Secretary to issue proposed regulations for nutrition disclosure. Final regulations must not take effect earlier than 2 years after promulgation. Restaurants are not required to provide certifications or signed statements. The Common Sense Nutrition Disclosure Act of 2015 requires restaurants to provide certifications or signed statements regarding compliance with menu board requirements. Definitions for "menu" and "menu board" are clarified, excluding certain types of advertising from being considered as such. The term 'preset standard build' refers to the finished version of a menu item commonly ordered by consumers. A 'standard menu item' is a food item prepared in the same way with the same components, routinely included on a menu at 20 or more locations under the same name. The Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act is amended to allow restaurants 90 days to correct violations before enforcement action is taken. Additionally, there is a provision for national uniformity in exempting certain subsections. The Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act is amended to limit liability for restaurants and retail food establishments regarding noncompliance with nutrition labeling requirements. Passed by the House of Representatives on February 12, 2016.
